reference: Daskin, M. S. (1995). Network and Discrete Location: Models, Algorithms, and Applications. Wiley.
math_formula:
$$
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Minimize} && \sum_{c \in \mathcal{C}} \sum_{p \in \mathcal{P}} \sum_{d \in \mathcal{D}} \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Z}} \text{VariableCost}_{c,p,d,z} \cdot \text{Shipped}_{c,p,d,z} + \sum_{d \in \mathcal{D}} \left( \text{FixedThroughputCost}_{d} \cdot \text{Selected}_{d} + \text{UnitThroughputCost}_{d} \cdot \sum_{c \in \mathcal{C}} \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Z}} \text{Demand}_{c,z} \cdot \text{Served}_{d,z} \right) \\
&\text{Subject to} && \sum_{d \in \mathcal{D}} \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Z}} \text{Shipped}_{c,p,d,z} \leq \text{Supply}_{c,p} \quad \forall c \in \mathcal{C}, p \in \mathcal{P} \\
& && \sum_{p \in \mathcal{P}} \text{Shipped}_{c,p,d,z} \geq \text{Demand}_{c,z} \cdot \text{Served}_{d,z} \quad \forall c \in \mathcal{C}, d \in \mathcal{D}, z \in \mathcal{Z} \\
& && \sum_{c \in \mathcal{C}} \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Z}} \text{Served}_{d,z} \cdot \text{Demand}_{c,z} \geq \text{Selected}_{d} \cdot \text{MinThroughput}_{d} \quad \forall d \in \mathcal{D} \\
& && \sum_{c \in \mathcal{C}} \sum_{p \in \mathcal{P}} \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Z}} \text{Shipped}_{c,p,d,z} = \sum_{c \in \mathcal{C}} \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Z}} \text{Served}_{d,z} \cdot \text{Demand}_{c,z} \quad \forall d \in \mathcal{D} \\
& && \sum_{c \in \mathcal{C}} \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Z}} \text{Served}_{d,z} \cdot \text{Demand}_{c,z} \leq \text{Selected}_{d} \cdot \text{MaxThroughput}_{d} \quad \forall d \in \mathcal{D} \\
& && \sum_{d \in \mathcal{D}} \text{Served}_{d,z} = 1 \quad \forall z \in \mathcal{Z}
\end{aligned}
$$
natural_language_example: A company wants to optimize its distribution system by deciding where to locate its distribution centers and how to allocate shipments from product plants through these centers to customer zones. The company has 3 product plants, 5 distribution centers, and 10 customer zones. Each product plant has a limited supply of commodities, and each customer zone has a specific demand. The goal is to minimize the total cost, which includes variable shipping costs, fixed costs for opening distribution centers, and unit throughput costs. The constraints ensure that supply does not exceed capacity, demand is satisfied, and each customer zone is served by exactly one distribution center.
